study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) could alleviate symptoms of allergic rhinitis by reducing histamine and inflammatory markers.
results_summary: PEA (Levagen+) significantly reduced allergy symptoms in participants with mild-to-moderate baseline scores and decreased histamine and inflammatory markers (IL-4, IL-8, IL-10, TNF-α), while the placebo group only showed a reduction in IL-4. No significant difference was observed in overall symptom scores between groups.
population_specificity: 108 participants with seasonal allergic rhinitis (101 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) could serve as an effective therapeutic alternative or adjunct to Amphotericin B (AmpB) for treating cryptococcal meningoencephalitis (CME).
results_summary: PEA alone did not significantly prolong survival or reduce fungal burden in mice with CME. However, when combined with AmpB, PEA showed an additive effect, improving survivability and fungal clearance, though it was less effective than the standard AmpB and 5-FC treatment.
population_specificity: Mice intracerebrally infected with Cryptococcus neoformans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of CoUltraPEALut (a combination of Palmitoylethanolamide and Luteolin) as an adjuvant to olfactory training in treating Post-Covid Olfactory Dysfunction (PCOD).
results_summary: CoUltraPEALut demonstrated significant efficacy in improving olfactory function compared to conventional therapy, suggesting its potential as an adjuvant treatment for PCOD. The meta-analysis included five studies with 441 patients, showing consistent positive outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with Post-Covid Olfactory Dysfunction (PCOD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) on intestinal inflammation and microbiota alterations caused by high-fat diet-induced obesity in mice.
results_summary: PEA reduced intestinal immune cell recruitment and inflammatory response, modulated tryptophan metabolism, and reshaped gut microbiota composition by increasing beneficial bacteria like Bifidobacterium and Oscillospiraceae. These changes promoted serotonin biosynthesis, improving intestinal function.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-fed mice with obesity-induced gastrointestinal and central nervous system disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of PLGA-based microparticles loaded with palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) for sustained release in treating posterior eye segment diseases.
results_summary: The study found that PEA-loaded microparticles exhibited a satisfactory safety profile in vitro on human retinal pigment epithelial cells and confirmed safety in vivo, suggesting potential for improved local administration of neuroprotective molecules.
population_specificity: Human retinal pigment epithelial (ARPE-19) cells and in vivo models (specifics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of olfactory training, um-PEA-LUT alone, or combined therapy for treating chronic olfactory dysfunction in post-COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: Combined therapy (once daily um-PEA-LUT with olfactory training) resulted in significantly greater olfactory recovery (89.2% improvement) compared to either therapy alone or placebo. Patients receiving um-PEA-LUT alone showed subclinical improvement more often than those receiving olfactory training with placebo.
population_specificity: 202 patients with persistent COVID-19 olfactory dysfunction lasting over 6 months.
effective_dosage: Once daily or twice daily um-PEA-LUT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) could serve as an effective therapeutic alternative or adjunct to Amphotericin B for treating cryptococcal meningoencephalitis (CME).
results_summary: PEA alone did not significantly prolong survival or reduce fungal burden in mice with CME. However, when combined with Amphotericin B, PEA showed an additive effect, improving survivability and fungal clearance, though it was less effective than the standard Amphotericin B and 5-fluorocytosine treatment.
population_specificity: Mice intracerebrally infected with Cryptococcus neoformans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in managing orofacial pain and its anti-inflammatory properties, while also encouraging further research on natural agents for pain relief.
results_summary: The study suggests PEA may be effective in managing orofacial pain, including conditions like BMS, OLP, and TMDs, due to its anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties, but notes a lack of clinical data to fully support its use.
population_specificity: Patients with orofacial pain, including neuropathic and nociceptive conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) and acetyl-L-carnitine (ALC) to ongoing pregabalin (PGB) and duloxetine (DLX) treatment improved outcomes in fibromyalgia patients.
results_summary: The study found that adding PEA+ALC to DLX+PGB led to significant improvements in pain (WPI), disease impact (FIQR), and symptom severity (FASmod) compared to continuing DLX+PGB alone. The improvements were statistically significant and sustained over the 24-week study period.
population_specificity: Fibromyalgia patients already on stable treatment with DLX+PGB.
effective_dosage: PEA 600 mg twice daily + ALC 500 mg twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether daily PEA supplementation (Levagen + ®) combined with resistance training affects lean body mass, strength, power, physical performance, and recovery outcomes (e.g., sleep) compared to placebo.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study appears to be a proposed or ongoing trial.
population_specificity: Healthy active adults aged 18-35 years who are not resistance-trained.
study_duration: 11 weeks (including 8 weeks of progressive resistance training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) as an analgesic agent for chronic pain through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: PEA significantly reduced pain scores compared to comparators (standard mean difference of 1.68) and showed benefits for quality of life and functional status, with no major side effects reported.
population_specificity: 774 patients with chronic pain, including neuropathic and inflammatory pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the bioavailability and biological effects of a combination of palmitoylethanolamide and Equisetum arvense L. in modulating nerve recovery and pain relief in neuropathic conditions.
results_summary: The combination successfully crossed the intestinal barrier, reached the target site, and modulated nerve recovery mechanisms after Schwann cell injury, providing initial pain relief. The study supported the efficacy of the combination in reducing neuropathy and modifying key pain mechanisms.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro 3D models used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the synergistic antinociceptive effects of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) combined with morphine or gabapentin and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that PEA combined with morphine or gabapentin produced synergistic antinociception, with experimental values significantly lower than theoretical predictions. PPARα and opioid receptors were implicated in these interactions.
population_specificity: Female mice with formalin-induced nociception.
effective_dosage: ED50 values were derived, but specific dosages for PEA are not explicitly stated in the abstract.
interactions: Synergistic interactions with morphine and gabapentin were noted, involving PPARα and opioid receptors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effect of palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) on apoptosis of retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells induced by all-trans retinal (atRAL) and explore its molecular mechanism.
results_summary: PEA reduced apoptosis and ROS production in ARPE-19 cells, improved retinal function, and protected RPE and photoreceptor cells in mouse models. It also inhibited key proteins in the ROS-JNK-CHOP signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Human-derived retinal epithelial cells (ARPE-19) and Abca4-/-Rdh8-/- mice (models of dry AMD and STGD1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a formulation containing micronized palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in reducing urothelial inflammation and to assess the synergistic effects of its combination with hempseed oil and maritime pine bark dry extract.
results_summary: The mixture of micronized PEA, hempseed oil, and maritime pine bark dry extract (Pelvipea®) at 230 μg/mL showed the best efficacy in reducing pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, and IL-8) compared to individual components. PEA alone reduced NF-kB levels at concentrations of 25-200 μg/mL.
population_specificity: In vitro bladder urothelium model using T24 cell line and macrophage-differentiated THP-1 cells.
effective_dosage: 25-200 μg/mL for PEA alone; 230 μg/mL for the mixture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) against Paclitaxel-induced toxicity in dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons.
results_summary: PEA significantly reduced Paclitaxel's adverse effects on neuron viability, neurite length, and soma size, while also improving neuron viability and neurite outgrowth when used alone. These findings suggest PEA has protective effects against Paclitaxel-related neurotoxicity.
population_specificity: Primary DRG neurons isolated from Wistar rats (6-8 weeks old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the distribution of N-acylethanolamines, particularly palmitoylethanolamide, in placental tissues to understand their potential role in the analgesic and wound-healing effects of amniotic and amniochorionic membrane grafts.
results_summary: Palmitoylethanolamide was the most abundant N-acylethanolamine in amniotic membranes (AM), with concentrations significantly increasing after decontamination. The study suggests these lipid mediators likely contribute to the anti-hyperalgesic, anti-inflammatory, and neuroprotective effects of AM/ACM grafts in wound healing.
population_specificity: Placentas collected after cesarean delivery (n=7).
effective_dosage: Not specified (concentrations measured in ng/g of tissue).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms underlying the analgesic effects of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in humans using a pain model.
results_summary: PEA significantly reduced repetitive heat pain, prolonged cold pain tolerance, increased pressure pain tolerance and conditioned pain modulation, decreased wind-up ratio and allodynia distance, and improved heat pain tolerance, demonstrating clinically relevant analgesic effects on peripheral and central mechanisms.
population_specificity: 14 healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in an experimental model of perinatal asphyxia (PA) in newborn rats.
results_summary: PEA treatment reduced PA-induced hippocampal damage and normalized the appearance of several reflexes, suggesting early neuroprotective effects in the immature brain.
population_specificity: Newborn rats subjected to perinatal asphyxia.
effective_dosage: 10 mg/kg, administered subcutaneously within the first hour of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether co-ultramicronized palmitoylethanolamide/luteolin (PEA-LUT) could restore impaired cortical GABAB-ergic activity and improve cognitive dysfunction and fatigue in long COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: PEA-LUT significantly increased long-interval intracortical inhibition (LICI) and long-term potentiation (LTP)-like cortical plasticity compared to placebo, indicating restored GABAB activity and improved cortical function. Short-latency afferent inhibition (SAI) remained unaffected.
population_specificity: 39 patients (26 females, mean age 49.9 ± 11.4 years) with persistent cognitive difficulties and fatigue after mild COVID-19.
effective_dosage: 700 mg PEA + 70 mg luteolin, administered orally twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) supplementation on proinflammatory biomarkers in unvaccinated, nonhospitalized adults recently diagnosed with COVID-19.
results_summary: PEA supplementation significantly reduced concentrations of sP-selectin, IL-1β, and IL-2 compared to placebo, indicating anti-inflammatory effects in COVID-19 patients.
population_specificity: Unvaccinated, nonhospitalized adults aged 19-53 recently diagnosed with COVID-19 via RT-PCR or antigen test.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in reducing diabetic-related peripheral neuropathic pain (PNP) and its effects on inflammation, sleep, and mood.
results_summary: The study found that PEA significantly reduced neuropathic pain, improved sleep quality, and lowered depression scores and inflammation markers (IL-6 and CRP) compared to placebo, with no significant safety concerns.
population_specificity: 70 participants with type 1 or type 2 diabetes and peripheral neuropathic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) for nociceptive musculoskeletal and neuropathic pain in clinical settings.
results_summary: The study found PEA effective in reducing pain compared to controls (p < 0.00001), with improvements in quality of life, functioning, and neuropathic symptoms, though results were limited by high heterogeneity and potential publication bias.
population_specificity: 933 patients with chronic pain, including nociceptive musculoskeletal and neuropathic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and tolerability of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) as an adjunctive therapy for negative symptoms in patients with stable schizophrenia.
results_summary: PEA adjunctive therapy significantly improved negative symptoms compared to placebo, with no significant differences in positive or depressive symptoms. Safety assessments showed no significant adverse effects or extrapyramidal symptoms.
population_specificity: Patients with stable schizophrenia on a stable dose of risperidone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmitoylethanolamide combined with luteolin (PEA-LUT) improves olfactory dysfunction and mental clouding in long COVID patients.
results_summary: PEA-LUT therapy significantly improved odor identification scores and reduced parosmia prevalence and mental clouding severity over three months, with notable improvements across patient subgroups.
population_specificity: 69 long COVID patients (43 women, 26 men; average age 40.6 ± 10.5) with chronic olfactory dysfunction, categorized by prior olfactory training exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential efficacy of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in treating long COVID symptoms.
results_summary: The study found a substantial difference in post-COVID-19 functional status (PCFS) scores between hospitalized and home care groups after PEA treatment, suggesting PEA may be effective. Smoking was identified as a risk factor with an odds ratio of 8.13.
population_specificity: Long COVID patients (33 participants, 10 males, mean age 47.8 ± 12.4) attending a neurological outpatient clinic in Italy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of palmitoylethanolamide as an adjunctive therapy for acute mania when combined with lithium and risperidone.
results_summary: Palmitoylethanolamide significantly improved manic symptoms compared to placebo, as measured by YMRS scores at weeks 4 and 6. No significant differences in extrapyramidal symptoms were observed between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients in the acute phase of mania.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic potential of ultramicronized palmitoylethanolamide (um-PEA) in improving mitochondrial bioenergetics, ATP homeostasis, and glutamate release in the frontal cortex and hippocampus of 3 × Tg-AD mice.
results_summary: Chronic um-PEA treatment improved mitochondrial function and ATP content in the frontal cortex but did not ameliorate impairments in the hippocampus or glutamate release. Age- and pathology-related metabolic changes in cortical and hippocampal regions were unaffected by um-PEA treatment.
population_specificity: Young (6-month-old) and adult (12-month-old) 3 × Tg-AD mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antiviral potency of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) against SARS-CoV-2, focusing on its mechanisms of action and potential as an adjuvant therapy.
results_summary: PEA reduced SARS-CoV-2 infection by ~70% through binding to the viral S protein and dismantling lipid droplets in infected cells, preventing viral replication. The study also noted PEA's specificity for SARS-CoV-2, as it did not affect other enveloped viruses like VSV or HSV-2.
population_specificity: Huh-7 cells (a human liver cell line) and viral models (SARS-CoV-2, VSV, HSV-2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and tolerability of a Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA)-based nutraceutical in patients with episodic migraine.
results_summary: The study found that PEA treatment significantly reduced headache days per month, analgesic use, and pain intensity, with no reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with episodic migraine with and without aura (25 participants, 22 women and 3 men, mean age 36.3 ± 12 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential therapeutic applications of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in treating neurodegenerative diseases by examining its neuroprotective, anti-inflammatory, and analgesic effects.
results_summary: The study found that PEA, particularly in micronized or ultra-micronized forms, demonstrated efficacy in counteracting neuroinflammatory conditions and slowing the progression of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Huntington's, and Multiple Sclerosis. Literature research supported PEA's ability to address damage typical of major neurodegenerative diseases.
population_specificity: Patients with neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Huntington's, Frontotemporal dementia, ALS, Multiple Sclerosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) could suppress inflammation induced by Toll-like receptor (TLR) signaling in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: PEA suppressed pro-inflammatory cytokine production in macrophages and inhibited IL-6 levels in dendritic cells and B cells. It also reduced mortality and serum IL-6 levels in mice treated with CpG-ODN plus D-galactosamine.
population_specificity: Lupus-prone MRL/lpr mice, mouse macrophage cell line, bone marrow-derived dendritic cells (BMDCs), and B cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic efficacy of oxygen-ozone therapy alone versus combined treatment with ALA + PEA and myrrh in patients with sciatica due to disc herniation.
results_summary: The study found that 77.8% of patients receiving combined treatment (ALA + PEA and myrrh) had complete pain remission, slightly higher than the 76.4% in the ozone-only group, suggesting comparable efficacy with a marginal preference for the combined approach.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral neuropathic pain (sciatica) from disc herniation confirmed by CT or MRI.

study_goal: The researchers theorized that Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) could be an effective nutraceutical for treating long-COVID symptoms, particularly fatigue and myalgia, by modulating immunity and reducing inflammation.
results_summary: PEA was suggested to mitigate cytokine storms, modulate cell-mediated immunity, and counteract pain and oxidative stress, potentially benefiting long-COVID patients with fatigue and myalgia. The abstract highlights PEA's anti-inflammatory properties but does not provide specific clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with long-COVID experiencing symptoms like fatigue, myalgia, and cognitive dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Palmitoylethanolamide and luteolin (PEA-LUT) with olfactory training improves recovery of olfactory function in post-COVID-19 patients compared to olfactory training alone.
results_summary: The intervention group (PEA-LUT plus olfactory training) showed significantly greater improvement in olfactory function compared to the control group (olfactory training plus placebo), with 92% of intervention patients improving versus 42% of controls. The magnitude of recovery was over 10-fold higher in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Patients with persistent olfactory dysfunction (>6 months) following COVID-19, without prior history of olfactory dysfunction or sinonasal disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of um-PEA as an adjuvant treatment for early-stage COVID-19 by assessing its effects on inflammation, oxidative stress, and immune response.
results_summary: The um-PEA-treated group showed significant reductions in inflammatory markers (CRP, IL-6, neutrophils-to-lymphocytes ratio), oxidative stress (FORT), and D-dimer levels, along with higher IgG levels against SARS-CoV-2 compared to controls.
population_specificity: 90 patients with confirmed COVID-19, randomized into two groups homogeneous for age, gender, and BMI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) could mitigate obesity-induced anxiety-like behavior and neuroinflammation in high-fat diet-fed mice.
results_summary: PEA treatment improved anxiety-like behavior, reduced systemic inflammation, restored neurotransmitter balance, attenuated neuroinflammation, and protected blood-brain barrier integrity in obese mice. It also counteracted inflammation and mitochondrial dysfunction in vitro via PPAR-α-dependent mechanisms.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-fed obese mice and human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review preclinical studies on palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) to assess its antiseizure potential, neuroprotective properties, and safety profile in epilepsy and acute seizure models.
results_summary: PEA supplementation reduced seizure frequency and severity in animal models, sometimes comparably to existing antiseizure medications but with a better safety profile. It modulated the peripheral-brain immune system and restored endocannabinoid levels altered during seizures, suggesting preventive benefits against neural damage.
population_specificity: Animal models of epilepsy and acute seizures (no human studies identified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of um-PEALut as an adjuvant therapy for improving dyskinesia and camptocormia in Parkinson's disease patients receiving carbidopa/levodopa.
results_summary: The addition of um-PEALut to carbidopa/levodopa treatment improved dyskinesia and reduced camptocormia, with complete resolution of leg and trunk dyskinesia and marked reduction in camptocormia during "off" states after four months of treatment.
population_specificity: A single Parkinson's disease patient with camptocormia emerging during "off" states.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential protective role of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) on nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and to reveal its underlying mechanism.
results_summary: PEA treatment significantly improved liver function, reduced hepatic pathological changes, and attenuated lipid accumulation and fibrosis in NASH mice. It also suppressed oxidative stress, inflammation, and reactivated impaired autophagy.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with NASH induced by a methionine- and choline-deficient (MCD) diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) could counteract enteric inflammation, relieve bowel motor dysfunctions, and modulate enteric glial cell activation in an Alzheimer's disease (AD) mouse model.
results_summary: PEA improved colonic motor activity, intestinal barrier integrity, and reduced colonic Aβ and α-syn accumulation, S100-β expression, and inflammatory markers in SAMP8 mice. It also counteracted hyperactivation of enteric glial cells induced by LPS and Aβ in cultured cells.
population_specificity: SAMP8 mice (an Alzheimer's disease mouse model) and SAMR1 control mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of ultramicronized palmitoylethanolamide in managing neuroinflammation and cognitive decline in aging animals, as a model for human Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Ultramicronized palmitoylethanolamide showed promising results in animal models of age-related neurodegeneration, suggesting it supports successful brain aging by rebalancing neuroinflammation. The supplement's pro-homeostatic effects and improved bioavailability were highlighted.
population_specificity: Canine and feline models of cognitive dysfunction syndrome, as a natural model for human Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) on osteoarthritis (OA) and elucidate its molecular mechanisms in MIA-induced OA rats.
results_summary: PEA reduced knee joint swelling, cartilage degradation, and serum levels of inflammatory mediators (e.g., TNF-α, IL-1β) in OA rats. It also normalized mRNA expression of inflammatory and degradative enzymes in the synovia.
population_specificity: MIA-induced OA Sprague-Dawley rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) combined with α-lipoic acid (ALA) could counteract the overproduction of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and inflammatory cytokines in a model mimicking COVID-19 cytokine storm syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that a combination of 50 µM ALA + 5 µM PEA reduced ROS and nitric oxide levels and modulated key cytokines involved in COVID-19, with the best outcomes observed when administered after LPS-induced damage. The results suggest PEA and ALA may help restore immune response activation and act as antioxidants.
population_specificity: Human epithelial lung cells in an in vitro LPS-stimulated model.
effective_dosage: 5 µM PEA combined with 50 µM ALA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the safety, tolerability, and dosing of THX-110, a combination of Δ9-THC and palmitoylethanolamide (PEA), in adults with Tourette's syndrome.
results_summary: THX-110 treatment led to significant improvement in tic symptoms, with an average reduction of over 20% in YGTSS scores within one week. Side effects were common but manageable through dose adjustments, and most participants opted to continue treatment in the extension phase.
population_specificity: 16 adults with Tourette's syndrome.
effective_dosage: 800 mg PEA daily (constant) and up to 10 mg Δ9-THC daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of ultramicronized palmitoylethanolamide (um-PEA) in reducing inflammation and lung injury in mice with LPS-induced acute lung injury (ALI).
results_summary: um-PEA reduced lung damage, decreased immune cell infiltration and cytokine release (IL-6, IL-1β, TNF-α, IL-18), and inhibited key inflammatory pathways (NF-κB, MAPK), suggesting potential as an anti-inflammatory adjuvant for lung injury.
population_specificity: Mice with LPS-induced acute lung injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a supplement containing Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) and Luteolin could improve olfactory recovery in COVID-19 patients with persistent smell disorders.
results_summary: Patients receiving the PEA and Luteolin supplement showed greater improvement in olfactory function compared to controls, particularly in those with long-standing dysfunction. The study found a negative correlation between time since infection and olfactory recovery, with no gender-based differences.
population_specificity: Outpatients with confirmed COVID-19 and persistent olfactory impairment lasting ≥90 days post-infection.
effective_dosage: Daily oral supplement (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of supplementing standard therapy with Kalanit® (PEA + ALC) in patients with peripheral neuropathy secondary to rheumatic diseases.
results_summary: Patients treated with PEA + ALC showed significant improvement in pain VAS and specific neuropathy scores compared to those on standard therapy alone, with statistically significant results across all analyzed conditions. The combination demonstrated synergistic benefits, including anti-inflammatory effects and better treatment adherence.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral neuropathy secondary to rheumatic diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, spondyloarthritis) and documented neuropathy for <12 months.
effective_dosage: 600 mg PEA + 500 mg ALC twice daily for 2 weeks, then once daily for 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in relieving post-herpetic neuralgia as a natural alternative to pharmacological treatments.
results_summary: PEA provided effective pain relief within 48 hours at a daily dose of 900 mg (10 mg/kg) in a patient with post-herpetic neuralgia, suggesting it may be a viable nutraceutical option for neuropathic pain management.
population_specificity: A 67-year-old male with post-herpetic neuralgia persisting for 3 years following shingles complications.
study_duration: Not specified beyond the 48-hour pain relief observation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of a genetically engineered probiotic (pNAPE-LP) producing Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in a mouse model of Clostridium difficile toxin A-induced colitis.
results_summary: The study found that pNAPE-LP significantly increased PEA production, reduced colitis severity (histological damage, inflammation markers), and restored tight junction protein expression, with effects mediated via PPARα. These benefits were abolished in PPARα knockout mice or with control probiotics.
population_specificity: Mice with Clostridium difficile toxin A-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review human and animal studies examining the effects of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) on biobehavioral correlates in autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: Studies indicate altered PEA levels and signaling in ASD, with PEA supplementation potentially reducing autism severity by improving language, social, and nonsocial behaviors. Neurobiological mechanisms may involve modulation of immune response, neuroinflammation, and PPAR-α activation.
population_specificity: Individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and animal models of ASD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of non-neuronal cells in pain signaling and evaluate the effectiveness of palmitoylethanolamide, particularly in micronized forms, for managing chronic pain in dogs and cats.
results_summary: The study found that palmitoylethanolamide, especially in micronized and co-micronized formulations, has anti-hyperalgesic effects and can be effective in managing inflammatory and neuropathic chronic pain. The compound's pain-relieving effects are mediated through receptor-dependent control of non-neuronal cells.
population_specificity: Dogs and cats with chronic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of ultramicronized palmitoylethanolamide (um-PEA) as an adjuvant treatment for SARS-CoV-2 infection, focusing on its immunomodulatory, anti-inflammatory, neuroprotective, and pain-relieving effects.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that um-PEA has demonstrated beneficial effects in vitro and in vivo, including immunomodulation and anti-inflammatory properties, supporting its potential as an add-on therapy for COVID-19. An FDA-authorized clinical trial is ongoing to further investigate its efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract refers to in vitro, in vivo, and an ongoing clinical trial without detailing participant demographics).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and endocannabinoid-enhancing effects of a novel PEA-glucuronic acid conjugate (GLUPEA) compared to PEA alone.
results_summary: GLUPEA increased cellular PEA and 2-AG levels, enhanced TRPV1 desensitization, inhibited MCP-2 release, and reduced colitis in mice, performing comparably to ultra-micronized PEA.
population_specificity: In vitro (keratinocytes) and in vivo (DNBS-injected mice) models.
effective_dosage: Same concentration as PEA (specific dosage not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential efficacy of a micro composite of Palmitoylethanolamide and Rutin (PEA/RUT) in reducing inflammation, oxidative stress, and vascular damage in a model of vascular injury.
results_summary: PEA/RUT administration reduced vascular morphological changes, inflammatory markers (MCP-1, ICAM-1, IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α), and oxidative/nitrosative stress (nitrotyrosine, PARP, NRF2 pathway) in a carotid ligation model.
population_specificity: Animal model (complete ligature of the left carotid artery in unspecified species).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the anti-inflammatory effects of a topical cannabinoid formulation containing palmitoylethanolamide in a dermatitis mouse model.
results_summary: The topical cannabinoid formulation reduced ear edema by 51.27% at 24 hours and 65.69% at 48 hours, showing significant anti-inflammatory effects, though less robust than the corticosteroid control.
population_specificity: Mice with induced dermatitis
effective_dosage: 0.9% cannabidiol and palmitoylethanolamide (exact dosage not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and anti-nociceptive effects of um-PEA and LAC, alone and in combination, in a rat model of carrageenan-induced inflammatory pain.
results_summary: The combination of um-PEA and LAC (1:1 ratio, 5 mg/kg) significantly reduced edema, thermal hyperalgesia, inflammatory cell infiltration, and myeloperoxidase activity in rats. Separate administration of the compounds did not produce the same effects.
population_specificity: Rats with carrageenan-induced paw edema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prenatal developmental toxicity of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in pregnant Wistar rats to determine its safety profile.
results_summary: PEA showed no adverse effects on maternal toxicity, embryotoxicity, fetotoxicity, or teratogenicity at doses up to 1,000 mg/kg body weight/day. Any observed variations were unrelated to PEA treatment, indicating high safety even at high doses.
population_specificity: Pregnant female Wistar rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) could reduce postoperative inflammation and fibrosis in extraocular muscles to prevent scar formation after strabismus surgery.
results_summary: PEA administration attenuated postoperative inflammation and fibroproliferation by activating PPARα, which suppressed TGFβ signaling pathways. Inhibition of PEA degradation produced similar effects, suggesting PEA as a potential therapeutic for postoperative adhesions.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing strabismus surgery (specific human or animal model not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the potential of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) as a nutraceutical, focusing on its anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory properties in infectious and respiratory diseases, and its possible application in COVID-19 care.
results_summary: The abstract highlights historical use of PEA (branded as Impulsin) for immunomodulatory effects in influenza virus infection and suggests its potential benefits for COVID-19, though specific study results are not detailed. The paper reviews existing evidence supporting PEA's anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory properties in infectious diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract (general focus on infectious and respiratory diseases, with potential application to COVID-19 patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the basal pharmacology of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA), focusing on its pharmacokinetic properties, biological effects, and potential clinical utility, particularly for pain treatment.
results_summary: PEA exhibits anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties with good human tolerability. Its effects are primarily mediated through PPAR-α activation, though other pathways (TRPV1, GPR55) are also involved. However, gaps remain in understanding its bioavailability, tissue distribution, and excretion.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human pharmacology review).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of ultramicronized palmitoylethanolamide and luteolin combination oral supplementation in treating post-COVID-19 olfactory dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found that ultramicronized palmitoylethanolamide and luteolin combination showed early promise in treating olfactory dysfunction, alongside olfactory training and platelet-rich plasma injections.
population_specificity: Patients with post-COVID-19 olfactory dysfunction.

study_goal: To investigate the efficacy of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) combined with other elements in improving symptoms of Diabetic Neuropathy (DN).
results_summary: The combination significantly improved pain, vibration perception threshold, and B12 levels in people with DN after 6 months of treatment.
population_specificity: 73 people with type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Diabetic Neuropathy (mean age 63.0 ± 9.9 years, 37 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Palmitoylethanolamide combined with Luteolin in improving olfactory dysfunction in long COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found that oral supplementation with Palmitoylethanolamide and Luteolin, combined with olfactory rehabilitation, led to greater improvement in olfactory dysfunction compared to standard care.
population_specificity: Patients with long COVID-19 experiencing olfactory dysfunction for at least 12 weeks post-SARS-CoV-2 infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the functionality of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) and support its use as a dietary supplement for managing chronic inflammatory conditions.
results_summary: PEA exhibits anti-inflammatory, analgesic, antimicrobial, immunomodulatory, and neuroprotective effects with no reported side effects. Advanced delivery systems have improved its oral bioavailability, enhancing its therapeutic benefits across multiple health applications.
population_specificity: Animals and humans (general population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) supplementation on retinal ganglion cell function, intraocular pressure, visual field, and quality of life in glaucoma patients.
results_summary: PEA supplementation significantly improved P50-wave amplitude, reduced intraocular pressure by 1.6 mmHg, and increased quality of life scores in glaucoma patients.
population_specificity: Stable glaucoma patients on topical monotherapy (mean age 66.6 years, 52.5% male, 87.5% with primary open-angle glaucoma).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of OnLife® (containing palmitoylethanolamide) in improving chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) symptoms in breast and colon cancer patients.
results_summary: OnLife® improved peripheral sensory and motor neuropathy in 31.1% and 37.5% of breast cancer patients and 16.9% and 20.0% of colon cancer patients, respectively. Patient-reported outcomes showed symptom reduction in 45.9% (paclitaxel-induced PSN) and 23.9% (oxaliplatin-induced PSN) of patients.
population_specificity: Breast and colon cancer patients previously treated with paclitaxel- or oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current knowledge on the potential antidepressant effects of Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) and its underlying mechanism of action.
results_summary: PEA targets PPAR-α and the endocannabinoid system, showing potential antidepressant effects alone or in combination with other antidepressants, though limited preclinical and clinical studies exist to confirm these effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and analyze the ABC transporter family in Panax ginseng to understand its role in transporting secondary metabolites like ginsenosides.
results_summary: The study identified 106 PgABC genes in ginseng, classified into seven subfamilies, with ABCG being the most abundant. Tissue-specific expression and hormone-induced responses (e.g., MeJA) were observed, with some genes showing significant upregulation under treatment.
population_specificity: Ginseng plants (in vitro adventitious roots)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of medicinal plants, including Panax Ginseng, in treating diabetes mellitus-induced erectile dysfunction (DMED).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on Panax Ginseng (Korean Ginseng) but mentions that medicinal plants and their ingredients may improve erectile function by regulating hormone levels, reducing oxidative damage, and promoting NO/cGMP pathways.
population_specificity: Animal models of diabetes mellitus-induced erectile dysfunction (DMED).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ginsentide TP1 from Panax ginseng could protect against doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity while preserving its anticancer efficacy.
results_summary: Ginsentide TP1 reduced oxidative stress, inflammation, calcium and mitochondrial dysfunction, and apoptosis in cardiomyocytes, zebrafish, and mice, while not interfering with doxorubicin's anticancer effects in breast cancer cells.
population_specificity: H9c2 cardiomyocytes, zebrafish, and ICR mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of hydroponically grown Red Panax ginseng root powder on perceived stress levels, emotional state, and cognitive abilities in moderately stressed adults.
results_summary: The study found that Panax ginseng supplementation significantly reduced perceived stress and negative affect scores compared to placebo, and improved response times in a spatial planning task. There was also a marginally larger decrease in depressive symptoms in the ginseng group.
population_specificity: Moderately stressed adults (N = 149)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether American ginseng extract could improve ovarian dysfunction by activating the BDNF/AKT/Bcl-2/Bax signaling pathway via miR-151-5p, using infrared thermal imaging to monitor effects.
results_summary: The study found that American ginseng extract significantly increased ovarian temperature, indicating improved blood flow and metabolic activity, and effectively activated the BDNF/AKT/Bcl-2/Bax pathway, leading to ovarian tissue repair and functional recovery.
population_specificity: Animal model of ovarian dysfunction (specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically analyze the multi-target pharmacological mechanism of Panax Ginseng for treating non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The study found that Panax Ginseng contains active ingredients that regulate lipid metabolism, inflammation, oxidative stress, and other pathways, demonstrating potential for NAFLD treatment. It highlighted the "multi-component multi-target multi-pathway" mechanism of ginseng.
population_specificity: Not specified (general NAFLD context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying the anti-cancer effects of ginsenoside Rg3, a bioactive compound from Panax Ginseng, against gastric cancer.
results_summary: Rg3 inhibited gastric cancer cell proliferation by binding to E2F proteins, disrupting E2F-DP heterodimer formation, and suppressing cell cycle-related gene expression. It also activated the p53-p21 pathway and inhibited cyclin/CDK-RB signaling, demonstrating strong anti-cancer effects in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: Gastric cancer cells (in vitro) and C57BL/6 mice (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how ginsenosides from Panax Ginseng enhance immune function by regulating the gut-metabolism-immune axis.
results_summary: Ginsenosides restored immune organ indices, boosted cytokines and immunoglobulins, improved gut microbiota diversity, corrected metabolic disorders, and activated the TLR4/MyD88/NF-κB signaling pathway.
population_specificity: CTX-induced immunodeficient mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of PgJAR1 in jasmonoyl-isoleucine (JA-Ile) biosynthesis and its impact on ginsenoside accumulation in Panax ginseng.
results_summary: The study found that PgJAR1 catalyzes the conversion of jasmonic acid (JA) to JA-Ile, promoting ginsenoside biosynthesis, but excessive JA-Ile levels can inhibit cellular growth and reduce ginsenoside production. Modulating PgJAR1 expression is crucial for optimizing ginsenoside yield.
population_specificity: Ginseng plants (in vitro and molecular analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ginsenoside Rb1 (gRb1), a major component of Panax Ginseng, could modulate Treg and inflammatory T cell populations to alleviate asthma symptoms.
results_summary: gRb1 increased Treg populations and decreased inflammatory T cell populations (Th17, Th1, Th2), reduced inflammatory cytokine secretion, and suppressed asthma symptoms in mouse models and human PBMCs from asthma patients and healthy donors.
population_specificity: Mouse asthma models and human PBMCs from both healthy donors and asthma patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a photocatalytic system using Panax notoginseng residue-derived hydrochar (PHC) combined with perylene diimide (PDI) for visible-light photocatalytic degradation of minocycline hydrochloride (Mino-HCl).
results_summary: The PHC/PDI system achieved 90.8% minocycline removal under visible light in 2 hours, with a mineralization rate of 73.7%. The system showed high stability and adaptability to various environmental conditions, and toxicity assessments indicated reduced harm from Mino-HCl degradation products.
population_specificity: Not applicable (environmental study, not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antifungal efficacy of linalool against Fusarium oxysporum, a pathogen affecting Panax notoginseng, and its mechanism of action.
results_summary: Linalool significantly inhibited Fusarium oxysporum hyphal growth, reduced spore germination by 43%, and spore yield by 99%. It disrupted ribosome biogenesis by inactivating TORC1, impairing fungal protein synthesis and growth.
population_specificity: Fusarium oxysporum (fungal pathogen)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Panax Ginseng's ginsenosides as non-toxic and effective alternatives for managing chemotherapy-induced side effects, particularly cardiotoxicity.
results_summary: The study found that ginsenosides from Panax Ginseng effectively mitigate chemotherapy-induced side effects, including cardiotoxicity, neurotoxicity, nephrotoxicity, hepatotoxicity, immunotoxicity, and hematopoietic inhibition, by targeting cellular mechanisms like oxidative stress and inflammation. Both in vivo and in vitro experiments supported these findings.
population_specificity: Cancer patients experiencing chemotherapy-induced side effects (not explicitly specified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of a nanomedicine (CDs@Zn@l-Arg) incorporating Panax notoginseng saponin-derived carbon nanodots for treating critical limb ischemia by promoting angiogenesis, macrophage reprogramming, and muscle regeneration.
results_summary: The study found that CDs@Zn@l-Arg effectively promoted endothelial tube formation, myosatellite cell proliferation, reduced inflammation and oxidative stress, and improved blood perfusion and limb function recovery in a CLI mouse model. The nanomedicine also reversed detrimental intercellular interactions typical of CLI, enhancing positive crosstalk between endothelial cells, macrophages, and myosatellite cells.
population_specificity: CLI mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the sleep-improving actions of ginsenoside Rc, a component of Panax ginseng, and its potential mechanisms.
results_summary: Ginsenoside Rc improved sleep duration, latency, fragmentation, and amplitude, upregulated clock gene expression, increased antioxidant-related gene expression, reduced stress-related gene expression, and activated the Pink1/Sir2 signaling pathway without addictive effects.
population_specificity: Drosophila (fruit flies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the research landscape of ginseng polysaccharides, focusing on structural analysis, pharmacological activities, and current research hotspots.
results_summary: The study found that China is the leading nation in ginseng polysaccharide research, with strong collaborations with South Korea and the USA. Research hotspots included structural analysis, pharmacological activities, and specific focus areas like gut microbiota and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Not specified (bibliometric analysis of published research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm the mechanism of Shengmai San (containing Panax Ginseng) in treating type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) by investigating its effects on the PI3K/AKT/GSK3B pathway.
results_summary: The study found that Shengmai San improved lipid metabolism, reduced oxidative stress, and alleviated islet tissue injury in T2DM rats by activating the PI3K/AKT/GSK3B pathway. Serum levels of TC, TG, LDL-C, MDA, TNF-α, and IL-6 decreased, while SOD and HDL-C levels increased.
population_specificity: T2DM rat model induced by high-sugar, high-fat diet and streptozotocin injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the protective effects of Ginsenoside Rd (GSRd) from Panax Ginseng in central nervous system diseases and analyze its related mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that GSRd effectively crosses the blood-brain barrier and plays a significant role in treating neurological diseases such as ischemic stroke, spinal cord injury, Alzheimer's disease, and Parkinson's disease. The results support its clinical application for neurological conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral effects of Korean red ginseng extract (RGE) and its fractions (GNSF and GSF) against H1N1 and H9N2 influenza A subtypes in various cell lines.
results_summary: RGE and its fractions significantly reduced H9N2 infection levels across multiple cell lines, but continuous treatment with RGE showed variable responses to H1N1, increasing infection in some cell lines. The study also noted elevated reactive oxygen species, altered inflammatory responses, and modulated autophagy activity in response to H1N1.
population_specificity: Various cell lines (e.g., A549, NCI-H292) infected with H1N1 and H9N2 influenza A subtypes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Ginsenoside Rg6 (G-Rg6) from American ginseng berry could improve cisplatin resistance in epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC) cells by suppressing fucosylation and inducing autophagy.
results_summary: G-Rg6 inhibited cell viability and protein fucosylation in cisplatin-resistant EOC cells, induced G2/M-cell cycle arrest via autophagy, and enhanced cisplatin uptake by modulating CTR1 expression. Combining G-Rg6 with cisplatin showed higher efficacy than cisplatin alone.
population_specificity: Cisplatin-resistant epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC) cells (A2780CP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how fermentation affects the ACE inhibitory activity and phenolic composition of pomegranate juice (PJ) under in vitro digestion.
results_summary: Fermented PJ (FPJ) showed higher ACE inhibitory activity and enhanced antioxidant capacity compared to non-fermented PJ. Sensory evaluation differences between FPJ and PJ were also noted.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of pomegranate seed oil (PSO) on cognitive function in individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: Participants who took PSO showed statistically significant improvements in global cognition, verbal episodic memory, and processing/executive functions compared to those who did not take PSO. The study concluded that PSO is beneficial for important cognitive domains in MCI patients.
population_specificity: Eighty individuals diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of different-sized pomegranate seed oil-based emulsions (coarse and nanoemulsions) in improving strawberry quality, reducing microbial contamination, and enhancing antioxidant and antifungal properties.
results_summary: Both coarse and nanoemulsions significantly reduced yeast-mold and mesophilic aerobic bacteria counts in strawberries, with nanoemulsions showing higher antioxidant capacity and greater reduction in fungal severity (A. niger and B. cinerea). Treated strawberries also exhibited higher total phenolic content compared to controls.
population_specificity: Strawberries (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (emulsion sizes: 1246 nm for coarse, 325 nm for nanoemulsions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of pomegranate peel extract in active packaging and high-pressure treatment on color stability, lipid, and protein oxidation in Iberian dry loins with reduced nitrate/nitrite levels during refrigerated storage.
results_summary: Active packaging with pomegranate peel extract improved protein integrity by reducing carbonylation but increased yellowness. High-pressure processing enhanced 4-HNE formation and induced thiol loss, while neither treatment affected malondialdehyde formation.
population_specificity: Iberian dry loins (meat product)
effective_dosage: 0.06 mg gallic acid eq./cm² (pomegranate peel extract in active packaging)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the microbiological stability and quality of pomegranate juice treated by isochoric freezing versus heat treatment under different storage conditions.
results_summary: Isochoric freezing (IF) maintained microbiological stability, color, antioxidant capacity, and nutrient retention better than heat treatment, with no spoilage microorganisms detected after 4 weeks. IF juice stored at 4°C or 24°C also had lower microbial loads than fresh juice.
population_specificity: Pomegranate juice (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatment conditions: -15°C/130 MPa for 24 h, storage at -10°C/100 MPa, 4°C/0.1 MPa, or 24°C/0.1 MPa).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective and therapeutic effects of pomegranate seed oil (PSO) in a sepsis model induced by cecal ligation puncture (CLP).
results_summary: PSO reduced neutrophil infiltration, alveolar wall thickness, and lung injury in sepsis-induced animals. High-dose PSO significantly improved renal parameters and oxidative stress markers compared to the sepsis group.
population_specificity: Animal model (sepsis-induced rats via CLP)
effective_dosage: 0.32 mg/kg (low dose) and 0.64 mg/kg (high dose), administered once at 1 hour post-CLP

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether treating pomegranate peel with tannase-producing bacteria could reduce its adverse effects (e.g., decreased nutrient intake) and improve its nutritional value for fattening lambs.
results_summary: Treating pomegranate peel with tannase-producing bacteria improved nutrient intake and digestibility compared to untreated peel, though digestibility remained lower than the control diet. The treatment also restored rumen pH, ammonia nitrogen concentration, and protozoa population, which were negatively affected by untreated peel.
population_specificity: Arabi male lambs (average weight 35 ± 3.8 kg, age 8 ± 1.0 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate Pomegranate Extracts (PE)-loaded sphingosomes for antitumor therapy, focusing on improving therapeutic activity and reducing adverse effects.
results_summary: The ethanolic pericarps extract (EPE) showed the highest bioactive content and antitumor activity. The optimized PE-loaded sphingosomes (F2) demonstrated sustained release, high entrapment efficiency, and significantly stronger anticancer effects compared to free extract in MCF-7, HeLa, and HCT116 cell lines.
population_specificity: In vitro cancer cell lines (MCF-7, HeLa, HCT116).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether pomegranate parts could attenuate oxidative stress, inflammation, and other risk factors associated with NAFLD, and ultimately prevent the disease.
results_summary: Pomegranate juice showed hypoglycemic qualities, polyphenols from pomegranate flowers increased liver-protective enzyme levels, punicalagin-enriched extract inhibited hyperlipidemia and hepatic lipid deposition, and pomegranate fruit consumption reduced liver damage markers and inflammation while improving antioxidant capacity in NAFLD patients.
population_specificity: Obese and diabetic patients with NAFLD (study included rats and human implications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of postharvest treatments (1-MCP and MeJA) in extending pomegranate shelf life and reducing chilling injury during cold storage.
results_summary: The study found that combining 1-MCP and MeJA treatments effectively maintained fruit firmness, membrane integrity, and delayed weight loss, color evolution, and polyphenol accumulation. MeJA alone or in combination also increased anthocyanin content, enhancing fruit quality.
population_specificity: Pomegranate fruit stored at 2°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a standardized punicalagin-enriched pomegranate extract on the gut microbiome, circulating short-chain fatty acids, and gut microbial-derived ellagitannin metabolite urolithins.
results_summary: Pomegranate extract supplementation increased the relative abundance of specific gut bacteria and circulating propionate levels, with a trend toward higher acetate levels. It also led to higher circulating urolithins compared to placebo, though microbial diversity remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers aged 25-55 years.
effective_dosage: 250 mg of Pomella® (containing 75 mg punicalagin) orally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pre-harvest spraying and postharvest dipping with zinc supplements (nZnO and ZnSO4) could extend the shelf life and maintain the quality of pomegranate arils.
results_summary: Postharvest zinc treatment significantly improved shelf life and quality metrics (TA, TPC, TSS, anthocyanin content, antioxidant activity, and weight loss), with ZnSO4 being more effective than nZnO. Pre-harvest treatment did not extend shelf life.
population_specificity: Pomegranate arils (not human subjects).
study_duration: 15 days (until decay in pre-harvest; postharvest duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pomegranate juice could mitigate aluminum chloride-induced oxidative stress and trace element imbalances in rats.
results_summary: Pomegranate juice increased antioxidant enzyme activity (SOD, CAT), raised glutathione levels, and reduced lipid peroxidation (MDA). It also decreased aluminum accumulation and regulated trace element levels, suggesting potential as a chelating agent against aluminum toxicity.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to aluminum chloride.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of pomegranate seed oil to reduce liver and kidney tissue damage in an acetic acid-induced colitis model in rats.
results_summary: Pomegranate seed oil treatment reduced liver and kidney tissue damage, suppressed NF-κB activation, and regulated apoptosis, suggesting anti-inflammatory and anti-apoptotic effects.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats
effective_dosage: 0.4 ml/kg and 0.8 ml/kg pomegranate seed oil

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of pomegranate intake on liver enzymes in various clinical conditions through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials.
results_summary: Pomegranate intake significantly reduced AST levels in long-term interventions (>8 weeks), obese individuals, or those with metabolic disorders, and lowered ALT and GGT levels in similar conditions, though heterogeneity and publication bias were noted.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity (BMI≥30) or metabolic disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of pomegranate peel on growth performance, intestinal morphology, and cecal microbial community in broilers challenged with avian pathogenic Escherichia coli (APEC).
results_summary: Pomegranate peel supplementation (fermented or unfermented) improved body weight, average daily gain, and intestinal villus height/crypt depth ratio in broilers, while also favorably modulating gut microbiota by reducing harmful bacterial shifts caused by APEC challenge.
population_specificity: One-day-old broiler chicks (120 males and 120 females).
effective_dosage: 0.2% fermented pomegranate peel (FP) and 0.2% unfermented pomegranate peel (UFP) in diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current research progress on migrasomes, including their biogenesis, functions, and potential roles in disease diagnosis and therapy.
results_summary: The abstract highlights migrasomes' pomegranate-like structure, their role in cell communication and mitochondrial homeostasis, and their involvement in physiological and pathological processes, but does not provide specific findings on pomegranate itself.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on cellular organelles, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to comprehensively summarize recent information on the extraction, purification, structural characteristics, biological activities, and structure-activity relationships of polysaccharides from Punica granatum (pomegranate).
results_summary: Pomegranate polysaccharides exhibit a wide range of beneficial biological activities, including anticancer, immunostimulatory, hepatoprotection, anti-psoriasis, and antioxidation effects. The study highlights hot water extraction as the most common method for isolating these polysaccharides and notes extensive investigation of their structural characteristics.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an up-to-date overview of the bioactive constituents and potential health benefits of pomegranate, including its medicinal properties and therapeutic effects.
results_summary: The study found that pomegranate contains bioactive compounds like hydrolysable tannins, flavonoids, and phenolic acids, which contribute to its anticancer, antioxidant, antibacterial, antiviral, hypoglycemic, lipid-lowering, cardioprotective, and digestive system protective effects. The review suggests pomegranate has potential as a functional food and nutraceutical.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the metabolic profiles of seven pomegranate cultivars and identify bioactive compounds contributing to larvicidal activity against Culex pipiens larvae.
results_summary: The study identified 24 metabolites in pomegranate peels, with cultivar 'Black' showing the strongest larvicidal effect. Key bioactive compounds correlated with larvicidal activity included punicalagin, quercetin-O-rhamnoside, quercetin-O-pentoside, and galloyl-HHDP-glucose.
population_specificity: Third instar larvae of Culex pipiens.
effective_dosage: LC50 values of 185.15, 156.84, and 138.12 ppm/mL after 24, 48, and 72 hours, respectively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of pomegranate supplementation on nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) by reviewing interventional studies in humans and animals.
results_summary: The study found potential beneficial effects of different parts of pomegranate (fruit, peels, seeds, or flower) on NAFLD improvement, though most evidence came from animal studies, highlighting the need for more human clinical trials.
population_specificity: Human and animal subjects with NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile and summarize existing evidence on the anti-ulcerative colitis effects of pomegranate and its ellagitannins, focusing on their mechanisms and therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The study found that pomegranate and its ellagitannins, particularly punicalagin and ellagic acid, exhibit anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, regulate intestinal barrier function and flora, and show therapeutic potential against ulcerative colitis in preclinical and clinical studies.
population_specificity: Preclinical animal models and clinical human trials (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effect of Punica granatum (PG) flower tablets versus corticosteroid therapy (Triadent) in treating recurrent aphthous stomatitis (RAS).
results_summary: PG flower tablets were significantly more effective than Triadent in reducing pain (VAS scores) and lesion size in RAS patients, except on Day 1. Both treatments showed significant improvement over time.
population_specificity: Patients with recurrent aphthous stomatitis referred to Shiraz Dental School in 2021 (30 participants, 50% men and 50% women, mean age 27.8 years).
effective_dosage: Three PG flower tablets daily for 6 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and assess the effects of pomegranate on women's health during and after menopause.
results_summary: Pomegranate significantly improved hot flashes severity, menopause symptoms, and high-density lipoprotein levels, but did not affect low-density lipoprotein, body mass index, or weight. The study noted inconclusive results due to small sample sizes and increased risk of bias from lack of blinding and randomization.
population_specificity: Women during and after menopause.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the viability of pomegranate as a natural treatment for prostate cancer and its potential to enhance current treatment protocols.
results_summary: The abstract mentions promising evidence that pomegranate, along with other natural agents and lifestyle choices, can be effective against prostate cancer, potentially improving existing treatments. However, specific results or data on pomegranate's efficacy are not detailed.
population_specificity: Men with prostate cancer (general mention, no specific subgroup detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the therapeutic role of flavonoid-rich foods, including pomegranate, in preventing cognitive decline and Alzheimer's disease, focusing on the BDNF signaling pathway.
results_summary: The study found that pomegranate, along with other flavonoid-rich foods, exerts beneficial effects on memory decline associated with aging and Alzheimer's disease, primarily through interaction with the BDNF signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on aging and Alzheimer's disease)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a citrus and pomegranate complex (CPC) on plasma levels of reactive α-dicarbonyls (α-DCs) in elderly subjects.
results_summary: The study found that CPC, containing pomegranate polyphenols, could scavenge α-DCs like methylglyoxal (MGO), which are linked to vascular complications in diabetes. The results suggest potential benefits in reducing AGE precursors.
population_specificity: Thirty-six elderly subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review studies exploring the anxiolytic-like effects of pomegranate (PG) and its phytochemicals to determine its potential as an alternative treatment for pathological anxiety.
results_summary: The review found 59 studies reporting anxiolytic-like effects of PG and its phytochemicals, with mechanisms involving GABAergic receptor inhibition, oxidative stress reduction, and modulation of various pathways. PG and its compounds could be considered a novel alternative for anxiety treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of pomegranate peel extract supplementation on hepatic status and metabolic syndrome risk factors in NAFLD patients.
results_summary: The study found that 1500 mg of pomegranate peel extract, combined with a weight-loss diet, improved metabolic syndrome risk factors (e.g., reduced body weight, waist circumference, BMI) and decreased hepatic steatosis in NAFLD patients after 8 weeks.
population_specificity: NAFLD patients (mean age 43.1 ± 8.6 years, 51.3% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of different parts of pomegranate on cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Pomegranate (juice, extract, and peel extract) showed potential anti-hypertensive, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory effects, and improved lipid profile by reducing triglycerides and increasing HDL-C in hemodialysis patients. However, the limited number of studies suggests the need for more clinical trials.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients
study_duration: Varied from one dialysis session to 1 year

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the dental applications of Punica granatum L. for treating gingivitis, including ethnomedicinal uses, clinical trial efficacy, antibacterial activity, mechanisms of action, and preclinical toxicity.
results_summary: P. granatum mouthwashes showed equal or better efficacy than chlorhexidine in treating gingivitis, though in vitro antibacterial activity against P. gingivalis was not clinically significant. The phytochemical punicalagin showed broad antibacterial potential, and flavonoids like quercetin may inhibit P. gingivalis proteases.
population_specificity: Patients with gingivitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a pomegranate-based food supplement (Improve™) combined with hydro-soluble vitamins in addressing prolonged fatigue.
results_summary: The pomegranate extract was chemically characterized, identifying 59 compounds, primarily gallotannins and ellagitannins. The clinical study involved 58 subjects randomized into two groups, but efficacy results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 58 subjects with prolonged fatigue (specific demographics not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of pomegranate juice on blood pressure through a meta-analysis of clinical trials.
results_summary: Pomegranate juice significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure, particularly at doses ≤300 mL/day and for durations ≤2 months. Higher doses (>300 mL/day) showed no effect on systolic blood pressure but still reduced diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: 573 individuals across 14 clinical trials (human studies).
effective_dosage: ≤300 mL/day and >300 mL/day of pomegranate juice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of pomegranate juice intake on inflammatory markers and complete blood count in hospitalized COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: Pomegranate juice significantly reduced inflammatory markers (IL-6, CRP, ESR) and improved some blood indices (neutrophils, lymphocytes, platelets, PLR, NLR) in COVID-19 patients compared to baseline. The PJ group also showed significant improvements in blood oxygen saturation and other secondary outcomes compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: Hospitalized COVID-19 patients
effective_dosage: 500 mL of whole pomegranate juice daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential mechanisms by which punicalagin (PC) from pomegranates may prevent or treat atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ACVD).
results_summary: PC and its metabolites demonstrated anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and anti-atherogenic properties, attenuating risk factors like dyslipidemia, oxidative stress, and endothelial dysfunction. However, deeper mechanistic insights and large clinical trials are needed to confirm these benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of in vitro, in vivo, and clinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the adverse effects of pomegranate reported in clinical studies.
results_summary: The systematic review found that pomegranate is generally safe, with only 11 out of 66 clinical articles reporting side effects, primarily gastrointestinal issues, flu-like symptoms, and allergic reactions. Most studies (21) reported no side effects, while 34 did not mention any.
population_specificity: Clinical study participants (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of medicinal plants, including pomegranate, in treating or modifying symptoms of multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The abstract mentions pomegranate among various medicinal plants tested for neurodegenerative diseases, but no specific results regarding its effects on MS are provided.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between pomegranate treatment and cognitive function through a systematic review of animal and human studies.
results_summary: The review found that pomegranate treatment was positively associated with improvements in specific domains of cognitive function in both animal and human studies. The included studies consistently supported the potential of pomegranate to enhance cognitive function.
population_specificity: Animal models and human participants (4 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of pomegranate juice on inflammation, oxidative stress, and sex hormones in women with PCOS.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but it indicates that the effects of pomegranate juice on PCOS-related inflammation, oxidative stress, and sex hormones are understudied and require further research.
population_specificity: 44 women diagnosed with PCOS (Rotterdam criteria) and BMI ≥ 25 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a polyphenol-rich beverage (containing pomegranate) on lipid metabolism and DNA integrity in healthy men.
results_summary: PRB consumption significantly reduced fat and protein intakes, increased fat-free mass, and decreased DNA strand breaks, while blood lipids remained unchanged. The placebo group showed increased body weight and leptin levels.
population_specificity: 36 healthy men
effective_dosage: 750 mL daily (containing 51% chokeberry, cranberry, and pomegranate)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the protective effects of pomegranate and its active components against natural and chemical toxic agents.
results_summary: Pomegranate and its constituents demonstrated protective effects against toxins like aflatoxins, arsenic, and carbon tetrachloride, primarily through mechanisms such as oxidative stress prevention, reduction of inflammatory mediators, and modulation of apoptosis pathways. No clinical trials were identified.
population_specificity: In vivo and in vitro studies (no specific human population mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of pomegranate juice/extract in reducing atherosclerotic progression by comparing voxel-based vessel-wall-plus-plaque volume changes between pomegranate and placebo groups.
results_summary: The study found a significant difference in vessel-wall-plus-plaque volume changes between the pomegranate and placebo groups (p = 0.0002), with the pomegranate group showing reduced progression. The proposed biomarker (ΔVVol%¯) was more sensitive than previous methods, requiring fewer patients to establish statistical significance.
population_specificity: Patients with atherosclerotic conditions (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of phytochemicals from Mediterranean diet food waste, including pomegranate, as sources of bioactive components with anticancer effects.
results_summary: The study highlights that pomegranate by-products contain biologically active compounds with anticancer properties, supported by molecular mechanisms that may aid in cancer prevention and treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on phytochemicals from food waste, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety of combining protein and pomegranate extract in healthy elderly individuals over a 21-day supplementation period.
results_summary: The study found no serious adverse events, with safety and tolerability comparable between the test (protein + pomegranate) and control (protein + maltodextrin) groups. Minor differences were observed in GPT and prealbumin levels, which decreased only in the test group.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects aged 65 years or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of pomegranate extract on liver enzymes, hepatokines, IL-6, and total antioxidant capacity in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Pomegranate extract significantly reduced ALT, AST, GGT, fetuin-A, FGF-21, and IL-6 levels while increasing total antioxidant capacity, but had no effect on ALP compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 44 patients with NAFLD

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an updated review on the ethnomedicinal uses, pharmacological activities, phytochemistry, and molecular mechanisms of Punica granatum L (pomegranate).
results_summary: The study found that pomegranate exhibits diverse pharmacological activities, including anti-diabetic, anti-inflammatory, and anti-microbial effects, and may improve gut microbiota. Clinical trials suggest benefits for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, metabolic syndrome, and other conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article covering various studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the preclinical and clinical evidence for the potential of anthocyanidins/anthocyanins, particularly from pomegranate, in treating and preventing prostate cancer.
